question.text: Two identical objects A and B are at temperatures TA and TB  respectively. Both objects are placed in a room with perfectly absorbing walls maintained at a temperature T(TA>T>TB). The objects A and B attain the temperature T eventually. Select the correct statements from the following

options.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> only emits radiations, while <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> only absorbs it until both attain the temperature <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>T</mi></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> loses more heat by radiation than it absorbs, while <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> absorbs more radiation than it emits until they attain the temperature <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>T</mi></math>

Both <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A </mi></math>and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>  only absorb radiation but do not emit it, until they attain the temperature <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>T</mi></math>.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> only emits radiations, while <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> only absorbs it until both attain the temperature <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>T</mi></math>

solution.text: Every object emits and absorbs the radiations simultaneously. If the energy emitted is more than the energy absorbed temperature falls and vice versa.
